Steps to reproduce
------------------
Connect from Windows to CentOS using Enter-PSSession:
```powershell
Enter-PSSession -HostName mercury -UserName maxt
```

Expected behavior
-----------------
To clear the CentOS linux screen.
```none

```

Actual behavior
---------------
Won't clear the host screen!
```none
PS C:\Program Files\PowerShell\6-preview> Enter-PSSession -HostName mercury -UserName maxt
The authenticity of host 'mercury (192.168.164.133)' can't be established.
ECDSA key fingerprint is SHA256:Oc1pH2zch7HLOqrCdOAioS5OVvRvucj7SRBcrC7jXyQ.
Are you sure you want to continue connecting (yes/no)?
Warning: Permanently added 'mercury,192.168.164.133' (ECDSA) to the list of known hosts.
maxt@mercury's password:
[mercury]: PS /home/maxt> $PSVersionTable

Name                           Value
----                           -----
PSVersion                      6.1.0-preview.2
PSEdition                      Core
GitCommitId                    v6.1.0-preview.2
OS                             Linux 3.10.0-862.2.3.el7.x86_64 #1 SMP Wed May 9 18:05:47 UTC 2018
Platform                       Unix
PSCompatibleVersions           {1.0, 2.0, 3.0, 4.0...}
PSRemotingProtocolVersion      2.3
SerializationVersion           1.1.0.1
WSManStackVersion              3.0


[mercury]: PS /home/maxt> cls
TERM environment variable not set.
[mercury]: PS /home/maxt>
```

comments.author: BrucePay
comments.body: So if you set the TERM variable e.g. `$ENV:TERM="ansi"` does it work?

comments.author: MaximoTrinidad
comments.body:
Hi @BrucePay,

Yes! It works.  So, is this something to be handle by the installation, to set TERM="ansi"??
:)

Thanks!

comments.author: BrucePay
comments.body: I think it's yet another aspect of #975. The TERM variable is one of the things that should have been set for you at shell start time. Anyway, are you OK with me closing this as a dup of the earlier bug?
